docs.lead_paragraph: About 80 percent of people who chose plans under the Affordable Care Act are paying initial premiums as required, several large insurers said.

headline.main: Insurers Say Most Who Signed Up Under Health Law Have Paid Up
headline.print_headline: Insurers Say Most Who Signed Up Have Paid Up

docs.abstract: Several large insurers report that about 80 percent of people choosing plans under Affordable Care Act are paying initial premiums required for coverage to take effect; disclosure comes on eve of House hearing about law.
docs.snippet: About 80 percent of people who chose plans under the Affordable Care Act are paying initial premiums as required, several large insurers said.

docs.lead_paragraph: Narendra Modi, the front-runner for prime minister, has a reputation in the state of Gujarat for brushing aside political and regulatory obstacles that stall construction in other parts of India.

headline.main: Local Policies Help an Indian Candidate Trying to Go National
headline.print_headline: Local Policies Help an Indian Candidate Trying to Go National

docs.abstract: Narendra Modi, front-runner in India's race for prime minister, has a reputation in the state of Gujarat for brushing aside political and regulatory obstacles that stall construction in other parts of India; because of Modi's efforts, Gujarat's economy has grown 10 percent a year, higher than the Indian average, for much of the last decade; some question whether his penchant for grand, earth-moving building projects makes sense when the state is still struggling with social problems like mortality and malnutrition.
docs.snippet: Narendra Modi, the front-runner for prime minister, has a reputation in the state of Gujarat for brushing aside political and regulatory obstacles that stall construction in other parts of India.

headline.main: Universal Mammograms Show We Don’t Understand Risk

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress has slashed billions in Pentagon spending but is fighting reforms needed to implement the cuts, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel said on Tuesday as his top generals went to Capitol Hill to urge lawmakers to slow the rising cost of military pay.

headline.main: Hagel Presses Congress to Support Pentagon Plans to Cut Spending
headline.print_headline: Hagel Presses Congress to Support Pentagon Plans to Cut Spending

headline.main: Text to Text | President Johnson's 'Great Society' Speech and ‘50 Years Into the War on Poverty, Hardship Hits Back'

docs.abstract: In this Text to Text, we pair President Johnson’s “Great Society” speech with an article by Trip Gabriel describing the new face of poverty in rural West Virginia.

docs.abstract: Our family is moving from Jerusalem to Rockland County, leaving almost everything and everyone familiar to our 6- and 2-year-olds behind. I am afraid for our family and our finances, and craving Doritos.

docs.lead_paragraph: The decision in Massachusetts follows months of problems with enrollment through its health insurance website, which worked well until it was revamped to comply with President Obama’s health law.

headline.main: Massachusetts Starts Over on Health Website After Troubles
headline.print_headline: Massachusetts Starts Over on Health Website After Troubles

docs.abstract: Officials in Massachusetts say the state will stop trying to fix its deeply flawed health insurance website and instead buy new software to help its residents enroll in coverage; decision follows months of problems with enrollment through state website, which Massachusetts set up in 2006 under its landmark health insurance law.
docs.snippet: The decision in Massachusetts follows months of problems with enrollment through its health insurance website, which worked well until it was revamped to comply with President Obama’s health law.

docs.lead_paragraph: The mortality rate in Massachusetts dropped sharply after the state overhauled health care in 2006, a study has found, offering evidence that universal coverage has saved lives, health economists say.

headline.main: Mortality Drop Seen to Follow ’06 Health Law
headline.print_headline: Mortality Drop Follows Massachusetts Health Law

docs.abstract: Study published online in the Annals of Internal Medicine finds that the mortality rate in Massachusetts dropped sharply after the state overhauled health care in 2006, offering what health economists say is evidence that universal coverage has saved lives.
docs.snippet: The mortality rate in Massachusetts dropped sharply after the state overhauled health care in 2006, a study has found, offering evidence that universal coverage has saved lives, health economists say.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Massachusetts blazed the trail of healthcare reform in 2006 by expanding coverage for the poor and requiring all residents to have health insurance, it may have done more than serve as a model for nationwide reform: it also seemed to save lives, according to a study released on Monday.

headline.main: Deaths Fell After Massachusetts Healthcare Overhaul: Study
headline.print_headline: Deaths Fell After Massachusetts Healthcare Overhaul: Study
